Title.text: Demonstrators Jailed

Description.text: Newspaper clipping of the front page of the Record. Shows a photograph of Barbara Kay and Mrs. Byron Baer being arrested for protesting as part of the Englewood Movement.

RepositoryName.text: pvt-coll

Title.text: Letter to Ulysses Kay from Hinds County Jail, back

Description.text: Letter from Barbara Kay to her husband Ulysses Kay. Barbara Kay participated in the Mississippi Freedom Rides during the summer of 1961. Arrested in Jackson, she was held in three jails including the Parchman Penitentiary for a total of about 60 days, after receiving a four-month sentence for "Breach of the Peace."

RepositoryName.text: nnc-rb

Title.text: Letter to Ulysses Kay from Hinds County Jail, front

Title.text: Letter to Ulysses Kay from Parchman Penitentiary

Description.text: Letter from Barbara Kay to her husband Ulysses Kay. Barbara Kay participated in the Mississippi Freedom Rides during the summer of 1961. Arrested in Jackson, she was held in three jails including the Parchman Penitentiary for a total of about 60 days, after receiving a four-month sentence for "Breach of the Peace."

Title.text: Englewood Movement Membership Card

Description.text: Barbara Kay participated in the Englewood Movement, the first sit-in in the North, when Englewood residents took over city hall to protest racial segregation in the schools in 1962.

Title.text: Opera/South third season program, unnumbered page 7

Jackson State College, Utica Junior College, Tougaloo College; Opera/South in its third season for Mississippi Inter-Collegiate Opera Guild. Performances of Highway 1, U.S.A. by Williams Grant Still; The Juggler of Our Lady by Ulysses Kay; conductor, Margaret Harris.
Pages 7 includes cast mini-biographies and portraits of Wilma Shakesnider, Marvin Wallace, Clyde Walker, and William Brown.

Title.text: Opera/South third season program, unnumbered pages 4 to 5

Description.text:
Jackson State College, Utica Junior College, Tougaloo College; Opera/South in its third season for Mississippi Inter-Collegiate Opera Guild. Performances of Highway 1, U.S.A. by Williams Grant Still; The Juggler of Our Lady by Ulysses Kay; conductor, Margaret Harris.
Pages 4-5 include cast lists, portraits of Wilma Shakesnider, Marvin Wallace, Clyde Walker, and William Brown.

RepositoryName.text: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Title.text: Opera/South third season program, unnumbered pages 2 to 3

Description.text:
Jackson State College, Utica Junior College, Tougaloo College; Opera/South in its third season for Mississippi Inter-Collegiate Opera Guild. Performances of Highway 1, U.S.A. by Williams Grant Still; The Juggler of Our Lady by Ulysses Kay; conductor, Margaret Harris.
Pages 2 and 3 include biographies and portraits of Wilma Shakesnider, Marvin Wallace, Clyde Walker, William Brown, Margaret Harris, and Donald Dorr. Includes biographies of Ulysses Kay and William Grant Still. Include synopses of The Juggler of Our Lady and Highway 1, U.S.A.

Title.text: Ulysses Kay receiving award from the University of Rochester

Title.text: Ulysses Kay with other members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters

Subject.text: American Academy of Arts and Letters

Description.text: Ulysses Kay was elected as a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters in 1979. He is shown here in this photograph taken in the early 1990s, sitting to the right of his former teacher at Columbia, Otto Luening, and with Jack Beeson standing just above him, to the right.

Notes.text: Date inferred from Ulysses Kay's Navy enlistment dates.

Title.text: Ulysses Kay at Bellagio Study and Conference Center

Description.text: Among the many tributes extended to Ulysses Kay was his serving as composer-in-residence at the Bellagio Study and Conference Center in Bellagio, Italy in 1982, where this photograph was taken. He received six honorary doctorates during his life, and attended a number of special "All-Ulysses Kay Concerts" and "Ulysses Kay Days" held at many colleges and universities including Lehman College, and even a "Ulysses Kay Week" held in the Boston area in 1988 when Harvard, Tufts, Northeastern, and the University of Massachusetts (Harbor campus) presented a series of all-Kay concerts from March 9 to 14.

RepositoryName.text: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Title.text: Ulysses Kay Music Composition Diary 1949-1990, 1967-1968, unnumbered pages

Description.text: Details trips to Long Beach, Davis California; Phoenix, Tempe Arizona; Evanston Illinois; Englewood New Jersey; New Haven, Connecticut; among other places in New York state, Atlanta, Chicago, etc. Also lists teaching position offers from various universities.

RepositoryName.text: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Title.text: Ulysses Kay Music Composition Diary 1949-1990, 1976, unnumbered pages

Description.text: In these two pages, Kay kept track of the progress of "Jubliee," his first three-act opera, based on a novel by Margaret Walker, with a libretto by Donald Dorr. It was premiered by Opera/South on November 19, 1977, Paul Freeman conducting.

RepositoryName.text: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Title.text: Ulysses Kay Music Composition Diary 1949-1990, 1958-1959, unnumbered pages

Description.text: "Trip to U.S.S.R." Ulysses Kay's Music Diary, 1949-1990: years 1958-59 detail his trip to the U.S.S.R., as well as other places in the United States

RepositoryName.text: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Title.text: Ulysses Kay Music Composition Diary 1976-1991, Frederick Douglass, unnumbered pages

Description.text: In this notebook, Kay kept track of the progress made on his last major work, the three-act opera "Frederick Douglass," also with a libretto by Donald Dorr. It was premiered by the New Jersey State Opera on April 14, 1991, with Kevin Maynor in the role of Frederick Douglass, and Alfredo Silipigni conducting.

RepositoryName.text: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

Title.text: Ulysses Kay Music Composition Diary 1976-1991, Operas, unnumbered pages

Description.text: List of Operas: the Boor (1955); the Juggler of Our Lady (1956); the Capitoline Venus (1970); Jubilee (1974-76); Frederick Douglass (1980-1985); information on the premiere of Frederick Douglass

RepositoryName.text: Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University
